verses.text: But thou, O God, \add art\add* gracious and true, longsuffering, and in mercy ordering all \add things\add*.
For if we sin, we are thine, knowing thy power: but we will not sin, knowing that we are counted thine.
For to know thee \add is\add* perfect righteousness: yea, to know thy power \add is\add* the root of immortality.
For neither did the mischievous invention of men deceive us, nor an image spotted with divers colours, the paintersâ€™ fruitless labour;
the sight whereof enticeth fools to lust \add after it\add*, and \add so\add* they desire the form of a dead image, that hath no breath.

Both they that make \add them\add*, they that desire \add them\add*, and they that worship \add them\add*, are lovers of evil \add things\add*, and \add are\add* worthy to have such things to trust upon.

For the potter, tempering soft earth, fashioneth every \add vessel\add* with much labour for our service: yea, of the same clay he maketh both the vessels that serve for clean uses, and likewise \add also\add* all such as serve to the contrary: but what is the use of either sort, the potter \add himself is\add* the judge.

And employing his labours lewdly, he maketh a vain god of the same clay, \add even he\add* which a little before was made of earth \add himself\add*, and within a little while after returneth \add to the same\add*, out of the which he was taken, when his life which was lent him shall be demanded.

Notwithstanding his care is, not that he shall have much labour, nor that his life is short: but striveth to excel goldsmiths and silversmiths, and endeavoureth to do like the workers in brass, and counteth it \add his\add* glory to make counterfeit \add things\add*.
His heart \add is\add* ashes, his hope \add is\add* more vile than earth, and his life of less value than clay:
forasmuch as he knew not his Maker, and him that inspired into him an active soul, and breathed in a living spirit.
But they counted our life a pastime, and \add our\add* time \add here\add* a market for gain: for, say they, \add we\add* must be getting every way, though it be by evil \add means\add*.
For this man, that of earthly matter maketh brickle vessels and graven images, knoweth himself to offend above all \add others\add*.
And all the enemies of thy people, that hold them in subjection, \add are\add* most foolish, and \add are\add* more miserable than very babes.

For they counted all the idols of the heathen \add to be\add* gods: which neither have the use of eyes to see, nor noses to draw breath, nor ears to hear, nor fingers of hands to handle; and \add as for\add* their feet, \add they are\add* slow to go.
For man made them, and he that borrowed \add his own\add* spirit fashioned them: but no man can make a god like unto himself.
For being mortal, he worketh a dead \add thing\add* with wicked hands: for he \add himself\add* is better than the things which he worshippeth: whereas he lived \add once\add*, but they never.
Yea, they worshipped \add those\add* beasts also \add that are\add* most hateful: for being compared together, some are worse than others.
Neither are they beautiful, so much as to be desired in respect of beasts: but they went without the praise of God and his blessing.
